body.p:
Covington
March 2, 1865
His Excellency
Govr Bramlette,
Dear Sir,

A judgment for $100 on a forfeited recognizance was rendered at the Spring term for 1859 of the Boone Circuit Court against Wickliffe Grubbs and Wm Grubbs, securities of one Evelina a slave belonging to a relation of said Messrs Grubbs, who had been held to appear on charge of infanticide; but who ran away from her owner -- just before trial.

The gentlemen who became security for -- this
unfortunate negress did so under promptings of humanity; and at the suggestion of Judge Elijah Nuttall, who was then on the bench. The woman, who was worth some $500, ran away from her mistress, without any fault of hers or that of the securities; being frightened at the idea of standing trial on a charge, of which I can say almost with certainty she would have been acquitted. My own affidavit, (having been counsel for the woman) accompanies the petition; and I have therein narrated the facts of this case.

No proceedings to collect the judgment have ever
been taken against the securities; one of whom (Wickliffe Grubbs) has since died; but it is deemed advisable to apply to your excellency for a remission under the circumstances
The case is one which I trust will command itself to the clemency of the Executive

very respectfully
& Truly Yours
R. Richardson
Should a remission be granted, please have the same mailed to

M. Hamilton
Burlington
Boone Co.
Ky.

His Excellency
Govr Bramlette
Frankfort Ky.

Boone Cir Ct
vs
Cashianne Grubbs
M. Hamilton
Exr of W WH W Grubbs
$100
14th Mch 1865
